answers.answer: A good friend of mine had gestational diabetes.. she had to watch her sugar intake.. (basically eat well - nothing too extreme) - she gained alot of weight (because she DIDN'T follow the doctors orders) and the baby was big (almost 10 lbs).. because SHE didn't follow the Dr.s orders, the babies blood sugar was REALLY low when he was born..they had to keep a close eye on him for a few hours before they let him out of the nursery. He also had jaundice, but I don't think that we related to the diabetes. Basically, SHE didn't do what she was told to do, so if you follow the rules you and the baby should be fine.

HI, My name is Becky and I am a type 2 diabetic.  I didn't know I was pregnant with my first until 12 weeks along.  At that point my sugars were 300 to 400 range because I had just found out I was diabetic and my dr was playing with my medication.So for the first 12 weeks of my pregnancy I had really high blood sugars.  After I found out I was pregnant I was put on insulin and controlled/watched closely.  My pregnancy went well and my daughter did not have any side effects to those first 12 weeks.  She weighed in at 6 pounds 2 ounces.  Feel free to ask ?'s

I am the person to talk to, lol!In 2002 I got pregnant with my son, ended up failing my 1 hour glucose, took and failed the 3 hour as well. I was put on a strict "diet" and had to check my blood sugar levels at home. I managed to keep my blood sugar levels under good control until 2 weeks before my due date. My levels started getting higher, I gained 3 lbs in one week so my OB decided to induce me 2 days before my due date. He used the gel twice, 8 hours apart, and then the next day lunch time my water broke. In the end, I had a c-section, my son was 9lbs 10oz and my OB told me that he was the reason I failed to progress (he was just too big). His weight was due to the gestational diabetes.Now on to this pregnancy. I am currently 36 weeks 4 days. I again had to take the 1 hour glucose test, failed and again took and failed the 3 hour test. We tried for a few weeks to control my blood sugar levels with diet alone but found that my levels were rising no matter what I did. As of Friday I am now on insulin. I have to give myself an injection of insulin 4 times a day as well as still be on the "diet".The "diet" I am talking about is: limit carbs, NO SUGAR, and lots of protein. The protein helps to slow down the digestion of the carbs.I have heard of people failing the 1 hour but passing the 3 hour, from what I have read (especially on the Maternal/Child forum of this site) it is actually quite common.If you have anymore questions, feel free to ask and I'll do my best to answer them.

here comes a barrage of questions lol..did your son (or your friends son for the first poster) have any effects from the diabetes as far as long term effects (more significnat than jaundice...).  i've had two normal pregnancies with my daughters and now this is a son and wham... it's like murphy's law... everything that can go wrong, is.As far as the strict diet... what does that consist of?  more so strict food or strict times?  my problem is this:  i just recently had my second daughter... she's 9 months old right now.  she'll be 12 months when this baby is born.  Anyone who has small children knows that a set suppertime with children that small is a joke...  for instance, i would have a hard time if someone gave me a paper and said "you need to eat at 8 am, 12 noon, and 5 pm with a light snack before bed".the more i read and the more I speak with people, the more i think im probably going to fail the 3 hour test miserably.  I've had a chronic yeast infection, which is new for me, and im just dizzy and tired more often than normal.  My sister (the mother of my insulin dependent diabetic nephew) seems to think that my number of 160 is more abnormal than what I originally thought, especially because I fasted prior to taking it.thanks for the comments tho... and please add to them... reading other people's stories kind of helps get me prepared for anything, if that makes sense.
Thanks very much for the offer!  I may just take you up on that after my 3 hour test.  I'll be sure to post the results when I get them.

My son had no last effects other than being a big baby. He will be 4 in January and is as normal as normal can be :).The diet is not really a time thing, it is more restricting certain foods and cutting back on others. I am supposed to have breakfast, lunch, snack, supper, nighttime snack. They are not a certain times but I am supposed to try and have 4 hours between my meals. Now with being on insulin, it's more of a set time thing, but that is because I have to "inject" myself 1/2 before I eat.For example, my breakfast is 2 peices whole wheat toast, 2 fried eggs, 2 pieces fried ham or bologna, 1 cup of milk.You have certain amounts that you are allowed. Like on my sheet it says that I am allowed milk with my meals and my nighttime snack but it is only 1 cup. I am allowed to have certain things anytime I want, they are called "free foods" - all veggies except corn and potatoes. Diet pop, crystal light and water.I am sure that if you fail the 3 hour, you will be sent to see a diabetic nurse and a dietitian, who will help you.If you would like, you can email me at sask_sweetheart at yahoo dot com.I would be happy to continue answering your questions and maybe even scan and email you some of the info that I have in regards to gestational diabetes.

I couldn't help but comment. I had GD with both of my children. Both times it was diet controled. I was also required to check my blood sugar 5 times a day. The diet consisted of my dr setting how many calories she wanted me to have a day, then my nutricianlist told me how many carbs and protein I would need with each meal. I also had to eat about every 2hrs. But b/c I kept my levels low my 1st ds was 7.13 lbs and my 2nd ds was 6.14 lbs. so it isn't really all that bad if you do fail. Just follow what your dr tells you. If your dr tries to make lite of it, do your own research or feel free to e-mail me at brandy_bodiford***@**** and I will answer any questions you have. Hope this helps. Best of luck tomorrow.

When i was pregnant the doctor thought i had GD. They tested and tested but couldn't prove it so they said i was glucose intolerant. My daughter was 11 lbs 2 1/2 oz when she was born. That was 7 years ago and she was born perfectly healthy and skinny as a toothpick now. Just wanted to share about my big baby.

Yes, make sure you update and let us know how you make out.Oh and a tip about the 3 hour, you may want to ask them if you can have a sip of water. I had to between my last 2 blood draws. I was so thirsty!!

I had gestational diabetes with my first daughter..  was able to control it with just diet.. she was born at a normal weight 7 lbs and 5 oz.. I did gain 70 lbs with her tho... she did have to have sugar water after delivery....that was in 2001..now I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in my blood in May 2006...  and may 18 2006 i found out i was pregnant.. so i took the 2 hour glucose test and the 3 hour glucose test...  in july 2006 i was put on insulin.. at first it was just at bedtime... now im on 2 types of insulin.. R insulin that i have to take before dinner.. and then the nph that i take at bedtime...  I have been walkin everyday since i found out i was pregnant so i was able to keep my levels good by exercising..  i am 36 weeks pregnant today and i have only gained a total of 25 lbs so far..    I am having a scheduled section cuz they arent sure if she will be big or not.. and im getting my tubes tied...

question: Does anyone have any personal stories regarding gestational diabetes they'd like to share?This pregnancy has been a tough one for me... Im the one who had to have the amnio due to the nuchal thickening on ultrasound (thankfully, the baby does not have Downs).  My latest "abnormal result" comes in the form of my Glucose Tolerance test at 28 weeks.  The doctor likes the number down around 120 and mine was at 160 fasting.  I now have to go through the three hour glucose test this weekend, but what I have read indicate that symptoms and risk factors are advanced age (which is me.. im 34.. will be 35 when i deliver), fatigue (uh, yeah), increaed urination (again, uh, yeah) and yeast infections, which I have also.  My nephew is a type 1 insulin dependent diabetic (I think he gets that from his father's side of the family tho, not mine and my sister's).anybody ever get abnormal results on their test?  the outcome?  anyone's children affected by that?  so on and so forth.. just looking for stories, thinks I should beware of, advice....
